node.text: "Wayfinding" systems are the smart design tools that help people navigate from place to place. It's a universal language that exists everywhere — from the roads we drive, the paths we walk, and the airports and malls we traverse. There's also a natural version in our brains. Without it, we'd be getting lost a whole lot more.

node.title: The Subtle Design Keeping Us From Getting Lost

node.text:
The 9/11 terror attack on New York killed 2,753 people and in the two decades since, the scale of the losses for the city and Wall Street still stagger. Three out of every four people who worked in New York for the brokerage Cantor Fitzgerald, 658 in all, died when the North Tower collapsed. 

At the boutique bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, 67 of the 171 New York employees were killed when the South Tower fell. At Aon, 176 were killed.

The list goes on. 

On this 20th anniversary, Wall Street looks back.

node.text:
Take Pokemon-like gameplay, throw in NFTs and you have Axie Infinity.

The game lets players like 22-year-old John Aaron Ramos accumulate tradeable crypto coins and earn real money — in his case, enough to buy two apartments. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Axie Infinity: How a Game is Turning Players Into Crypto Traders

node.text: NFTs burst on the scene with a $69 million sale of Beeple's digital art. Now players behind the so-called metaverse are betting "digital scarcity" will create a whole new ecosystem of play and commerce.

node.title: How NFTs Are Reinventing the Digital World

node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, indoor and text that says 'Solstr Here's what the next six months of the pandemic will bring Bloomberg'.

node.text:
For anyone hoping to see light at the end of the Covid-19 tunnel over the next three to six months, scientists have some bad news: Brace for more of what we’ve already been through.

With billions of people around the world yet to be vaccinated and little chance of eliminating the virus, we can expect more outbreaks in classrooms, on public transport and in workplaces over the coming months.

Almost everyone will be either infected or vaccinated before the pandemic ends. Read what experts say at the link in bio.

node.text: "Wayfinding" systems are the smart design tools that help people navigate from place to place. It's a universal language that exists everywhere — from the roads we drive, the paths we walk, and the airports and malls we traverse. There's also a natural version in our brains. Without it, we'd be getting lost a whole lot more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Business on September 12, 2021 tagging @bloombergopinion. May be an image of money and text that says 'After a terrible 2020, the dollar has come roaring back this year 4578717 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
💸Extraordinarily loose fiscal policy has flooded the world with dollars, writes @bloombergopinion's Richard Cookson.

Federal Reserve monetary policy at the moment is absurd. Deeply negative real rates are unjustifiable in an economy running as hot as America’s. All they are doing is fostering excessive speculation, as evidenced by the stock and housing markets.

The longer this inflation surge lasts — and Cookson's pretty certain it will last, albeit probably not quite so dramatically — the more pressure builds on the Fed.

Are economic conditions likely to favor the U.S. over its trading partners in coming months? Tap the link in our bio to read Cookson's prediction.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'a HowaScholz-led Scholz governmentcould transform Germany and Europe SPD Politik für Soziale Dich. Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Olaf Scholz is the favorite to become Germany’s next chancellor. But polls suggest the Social Democrat will need a messy three-party coalition to form a government.

The path to power for the SPD and its preferred partner, the Green Party, is complicated. It would probably involve either a more centrist alliance with the business-friendly Free Democrats, or a shift in the opposite direction in a tie-up with the anti-capitalist Left party.

The two potential alliances have big implications for Europe’s biggest economy, from taxes and banking to climate policy and EU relations. Tap the link in our bio for a topic-by-topic guide.

📷: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text that says 'CFAisstillthe is still CFA cheapest path to a career in finance. Is stress worth Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
The CFA exam has been held up as a no-nonsense, low-cost path to getting a foot in the door of the otherwise still-clubby world of high finance. The only catch? It can take longer to achieve than an MBA and most don’t even pass.

The plunging pass rates have prompted some to question whether all the positive attributes of the CFA program — the meritocracy, the accessibility, the affordability — are outweighed by the strains on candidates’ time and effort. Is it still worth taking? Read more at the link in bio.

📷: Spencer Platt/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 11, 2021. May be an image of screen and text that says 'Remote-controlled robocarsare about to hit the road O Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Developing and deploying fleets of autonomous vehicles has proven tougher than the likes of Tesla and Alphabet's Waymo had thought. A German startup is betting that teledriving will fill the gap.

Vay has been quietly testing remote-controlled electric cars all over Berlin. They plan to roll out a mobility service in Europe and potentially the U.S. in a matter of months, years ahead of the likely arrival of self-driving cars.

For a fraction of the price of an Uber, customers will be able to order a car, drive themselves to their desired destination and then get out, leaving it to a human teledriver miles away to either park the vehicle or steer it to a next client. See more via the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing, outdoors and text that says 'The world remembers the 9/11 terrorist attacks, 20 yearson Bloomberg'.

node.text:
People across America and around the globe have marked the 20th anniversary of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

Two decades ago, the world froze as four hijacked planes slammed into the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and a Pennsylvania field. Nearly 3,000 people lost their lives.

President Joe Biden, the Obamas and the Clintons joined crowds at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, observing moments of silence and listening as the names of those killed in the attacks were read aloud.

In the years since, foreign policy has been upended, travel and security has been reshaped, and New York City has been transformed. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Gallery: 

1. Katie Mascali is comforted by her fiance, Andre Jabban, as they stand near the name of her father, Joseph Mascali, during a ceremony at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum. (Craig Ruttle - Pool / Getty Images)

2. Former Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, President Joe Biden and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg stand for the national during the annual 9/11 Commemoration Ceremony. (Chip Somodevilla/Pool/AFP via Getty Images)

3. A man reacts during a remembrance ceremony at the Pentagon in Washington, DC. (Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images)

4. A fireman holds up the image of a 9/11 victim. (Jim Watson/AFP via Getty Images)

5. People gather in lower Manhattan near Ground Zero. (Spencer Platt / Getty Images)

Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'The "Jedi ”" of crypto is rolling out new blockchain fund Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
When Simon Seojoon Kim started investing his life savings in Ether, his friends told him he was crazy. Then the coin began to climb.

Kim says he made his first Ether purchase in 2015, putting in $400,000 by early 2017. Now, at the age of 36, he’s one of South Korea’s most famous blockchain advocates. Boston Consulting Group's Sean Park says "he is like Yoda, the Jedi Master of cryptocurrency."

After co-founding Hashed, a kind of venture capital firm for projects in the field, Kim raised his first blockchain fund in December. A second one is now planned this month. Tap the link in bio for his story.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says '8000000 00000000 2000000 Crazy Rich Asians star Henry Golding shares his genius travel hacks Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Henry Golding was once a globe-trotting TV host before he became an overnight leading man when he starred as Nick Young in Crazy Rich Asians three years ago.

Since then, the British-Malaysian actor has featured in many movies including Last Christmas and the just-released Snake Eyes: GI Joe Origins.

From getting face massages and haircuts in Rajasthan to trying horse meat sashimi in Kazakhstan, the 34-year-old has the secret to turning yourself into your own best local tour guide. Click the link in bio to read some of his genius travel hacks.

node.text:
The 9/11 terror attack on New York killed 2,753 people and in the two decades since, the scale of the losses for the city and Wall Street still stagger. Three out of every four people who worked in New York for the brokerage Cantor Fitzgerald, 658 in all, died when the North Tower collapsed. 

At the boutique bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, 67 of the 171 New York employees were killed when the South Tower fell. At Aon, 176 were killed.

The list goes on. 

On this 20th anniversary, Wall Street looks back.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Ajudge deals a huge blow to the App Store in Epic antitrust case Bloomberg'.

node.text:
In one of the most highly anticipated rulings facing big tech, Apple’s been told by a judge to change how it operates its lucrative App Store. 

Apple was ordered to allow developers to steer consumers to outside payment methods for mobile apps, in a ruling that is a severe blow to the iPhone maker. 

A federal judge granted an injunction sought by Epic Games Friday while also ordering the game maker to pay damages to Apple for breach of contract. The order could take a big bite out of the profitability of the App Store. According to analysts the App Store takes in more than $20 billion a year with a profit margin above 75%.

The decision is a significant setback for the world’s most valuable company as it faces growing antitrust scrutiny from lawmakers and global regulators. 

Apple is expected to appeal, setting the stage for the fight to carry on for at least another year and possibly make its way to the U.S. Supreme Court. Read more in our link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Renate Nyborg is appointed Tinder's first female CEO Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Match has named Renate Nyborg as the new CEO of its leading brand, Tinder.

Nyborg most recently served as Tinder’s general manager of Europe, Middle East and Africa. She joined the company in October from mental-health startup Headspace, and previously spent four years at Apple.

The first female CEO since Tinder’s inception also has first-hand experience on the dating app — she met her husband on it. Tap the link in our bio for more on her rise.
